✖

November 10th, 2020

By: Brennan K. Brown

Alright, letâ€™s get into the weeds this week (or perhaps flowers?). Overall, I think Iâ€™ve found a good equilibrium with Beeminder. I donâ€™t often derail, but at the same time I have over a dozen beemergencies every single day.

Iâ€™m also really happy for the spread of systems I have, finding ways to track my mental health, physical health, hobbies, and both creative and technical projects.

Regarding French, Iâ€™ve been stuck in the Emerald league forever in /duolingo, but progressing down the tree nonetheless. /clozemaster is definitely a welcomed addition, as the lessons are a lot quicker and give a more nuanced look at how words are actually used.

Since I began tracking /writing in May, Iâ€™ve written over 100,000 words, which is crazy to me. Although a good portion is just private journal writing, Iâ€™m still happy Iâ€™m doing it everyday. Before, Iâ€™d really try to win NaNoWriMo every year (anybody participating, btw?) and always fall short because I never wrote >1,500 words a day otherwise. I suppose Iâ€™d rather write ~400 words a day indefinitely than risk pushing and burning myself out.

Iâ€™m still finding a bug (or maybe feature) where /meditation doesnâ€™t add data if youâ€™re repeating a guided meditation. Iâ€™ve switched over to doing simple timed meditation with Insight Timer and that seems to work instead!

I recently derailed on /fitness by just a couple hundred steps, which initially seemed silly. But in reality, I have to remind myself that whatever Iâ€™m tracking on Beeminder is the bare-minimum threshold, and I gotta pass it everyday no matter what.

One thing Iâ€™ve noticed that I talked about on the Beeminder Discord (which you should join!) is that all my systems ultimately fall within two categories: input-based vs. output-based.

Now, when I originally began with Beeminder many years ago, I had the rhetoric that you should aim for looking at input rather that output. Which I still believe is betterâ€“but why not both if thatâ€™s an option?

There are a few examples of this: /writing is the input, and other goals like /blogging or /poetry are output. (A caveat being that writing is fortunately easy to both quantify and automate.)

Output-based goals that Iâ€™ve been having the most trouble with are the ones that I havenâ€™t really found a good input-based supplementary goal to add to it. I do really well with beemergencys pushing me towards doing work, but output goals donâ€™t have a daily metric, theyâ€™re usually weekly or monthly.

I finally had the brilliant idea to use RescueTime and track the amount of time that Iâ€™m specifically on Lynda each day to supplement /courses. I had a few good ideas for tracking pages read or time with /books, but I often get weasel-y if the data isnâ€™t automated. ğŸ˜… So itâ€™d be nice to figure out a way to connect with Kindle or Audible.

(P.S. Working on a new Jekyll theme this week, Purelog!)
